items.title: Silver, platinum surge as investors await US inflation data

featured_image.name: Silver hit record highs in 2025 – here's why the 'Devil's metal' has further to run

items.description:
Gold prices held steady near all-time highs on Thursday while silver hovered close to a record and platinum extended its meteoric rise, as investors awaited key US inflation data and a wave of central bank decisions.

Spot gold traded at $4,334 per ounce as of Thursday morning, roughly $50 below the record high of $4,382 reached in October[1][2]. The metal has surged 65% this year[3][4], driven by central bank purchases and investor flight from government bonds. Meanwhile, spot silver rose to $66.48 per ounce[3][2], just below its all-time high of $66.88 set on Wednesday[2][5][6], marking a stunning 130% gain for 2025[3][2].

Platinum outperformed both metals, climbing 2.9% to $1,953[3] and touching $1,977[7], its highest level since 2008[8]. The metal has surged 18% this month alone[9][8] and more than doubled in value this year[10], as banks store metal in the US to mitigate tariff risks and China's new futures exchange boosts demand[8][10].

items.title: US admits fault in DC helicopter-plane crash that killed 67

featured_image.name: Army and FAA admit failures in deadly mid-air crash at DC's Reagan National Airport

items.description:
The US government acknowledged Wednesday it bears responsibility for the January collision between an Army Black Hawk helicopter and an American Airlines regional jet near Washington that killed all 67 people aboard both aircraft, marking a significant development in what has become one of the deadliest aviation disasters on American soil in more than two decades[1][2][3][4].

In a 209-page court filing responding to the first federal lawsuit filed by victims' families, Justice Department attorneys stated that "the United States admits that it owed a duty of care to plaintiffs, which it breached, thereby proximately causing the tragic accident" on January 29[1][2][5]. The admission cited failures by both Army helicopter pilots who did not maintain adequate vigilance to avoid other aircraft and an air traffic controller who violated Federal Aviation Administration procedures regarding visual separation[1][3][4].

items.title: Scientists create 19.2-attosecond X-ray pulse to track electrons

featured_image.name: Scientists produce high-power attosecond X-ray pulses at ...

items.description:
Researchers at ICFO in Spain have generated the shortest soft X-ray pulse ever measured at 19.2 attoseconds, breaking through the atomic unit of time and enabling scientists to observe electron dynamics with unprecedented precision.

The pulse, reported in the journal *Ultrafast Science*, is shorter than the atomic unit of time—24.2 attoseconds, the duration it takes an electron to orbit a hydrogen atom once[1][2][3]. The achievement surpasses the previous record of 43 attoseconds set by ETH Zurich in 2017[4][5].

items.title: Korean team develops expandable wheel for lunar caves

featured_image.name: An 'origami' airless wheel to explore lunar caves

items.description:
A research team from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) and the Unmanned Exploration Laboratory (UEL) has developed an origami-inspired deployable wheel capable of navigating the Moon's steep terrain, including lunar pits and lava tubes[1][2][3]. The technology was published in the December issue of Science Robotics[2][4][3].

The wheel addresses a critical challenge in lunar exploration: small rovers struggle to traverse rugged terrain because their compact wheels lack the size needed to climb obstacles. Lunar lava tubes are considered prime candidates for future human habitats due to their natural protection from cosmic radiation and extreme temperatures, but their steep entrances have remained largely inaccessible to conventional rovers[1][2][3].

items.title: Asian markets fall on AI doubts, BOJ rate hike ahead

featured_image.name: BOJ to hike rates to 0.75% in Dec, 1.0% by next Sept, majority of economists say: Reuters poll

items.description:
Asian markets tumbled Thursday as investors retreated from technology stocks amid mounting concerns over artificial intelligence valuations, while anticipation of a Bank of Japan rate hike and key U.S. inflation data added to the cautious sentiment sweeping the region.

Japan's Nikkei 225 led regional losses, falling 1.53% at the open, with South Korea's Kospi declining 1.36% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropping 0.76%[1][2][3]. The downturn followed a sharp sell-off on Wall Street, where the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite plunged 1.81% and the S&P 500 slid 1.16%[2].

items.title: S&P 500 futures rise as investors await inflation data

featured_image.name: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq futures rise as Micron boosts tech after sell-off, CPI report looms

items.description:
U.S. stock futures edged higher early Thursday as investors looked past a four-day losing streak in equities, buoyed by strong earnings from chipmaker Micron Technology and awaiting a key inflation report that could influence Federal Reserve policy[1][2][3].

S&P 500 futures climbed 0.3% while Nasdaq 100 futures advanced 0.4%, pointing to a potential rebound after significant declines in technology stocks[1][4]. Dow Jones Industrial Average futures remained roughly flat[1][2].

Micron's stock surged more than 7% in after-hours trading Wednesday after the memory chip maker reported fiscal first-quarter revenue of $13.64 billion, exceeding Wall Street expectations, and provided an optimistic outlook for the current quarter[5]. The company projected adjusted earnings per share of $8.42 for the second quarter, nearly double the $4.49 analysts had anticipated, signaling robust demand from the artificial intelligence sector[6][5].

items.title: Brain-inspired computing could slash AI energy use

featured_image.name: How can AI be more energy efficient? Researchers look to ...

items.description: Two new studies released this week propose solutions to artificial intelligence's mounting energy crisis by taking inspiration from the most efficient computer known: the human brain. Researchers at Cornell Tech and Purdue University have independently developed methods that could dramatically reduce the electricity consumption of AI systems, which currently rivals that of entire nations.

items.title: Trump promises housing reforms as affordability crisis persists

featured_image.name: Mortgage rates hit fresh 2025 lows despite Trump-Fed drama

items.description:
President Donald Trump pledged to introduce "some of the most aggressive housing reform plans in American history" during a prime-time address to the nation Wednesday, as Americans face persistent affordability challenges in the housing market[1][2][3].

Speaking from the White House, Trump said he would unveil the reforms early in the new year and announced plans to nominate a new Federal Reserve chairman who supports "lower interest rates, by a lot," signaling potential changes to monetary policy that could impact mortgage rates[1][2][4]. Current Fed Chair Jerome Powell's term expires in May 2026, with National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett and former Fed Governor Kevin Warsh emerging as top contenders for the position[5][6][7].

items.title: Astronomers detect possible first superkilonova and earliest known supernova

featured_image.name: 'We were amazed': Scientists using James Webb telescope may have discovered the earliest supernova in the known universe

items.description:
Scientists have announced two landmark cosmic discoveries within a week, potentially observing both the first "superkilonova" and the most distant supernova ever detected, offering new windows into stellar death and the early universe.

The James Webb Space Telescope confirmed the earliest known supernova, designated GRB 250314A, which exploded when the universe was only 730 million years old, according to papers published December 9 in the journal Astronomy & Astrophysics[1][2][3]. Separately, researchers reported evidence for the first possible "superkilonova" — a hybrid cosmic explosion combining a supernova with a kilonova — in findings published this month in The Astrophysical Journal Letters[4][5][6].

items.title: OpenAI launches ChatGPT app store with Apple Music integration

featured_image.name: ChatGPT's Apple Music Integration Is Now Live

items.description:
OpenAI opened its ChatGPT platform to developer app submissions on Wednesday, marking the official launch of an app directory that allows users to browse and integrate third-party services directly into the chatbot. Among the first offerings is a newly launched Apple Music integration, which enables users to discover songs and create playlists using conversational AI.

The announcement represents the culmination of efforts that began in October 2025, when OpenAI first unveiled its Apps SDK at its DevDay conference. At the time, CEO Sam Altman told developers the company was building "a new generation of apps that are interactive, adaptive, and personalized"[1][2][3]. ChatGPT now serves 800 million weekly active users[3].

items.title: Judge orders Trump to reverse federal worker layoffs

featured_image.name: Trump admin broke spending deal agreement to halt mass ...

items.description:
A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the Trump administration violated the law by proceeding with hundreds of federal employee layoffs despite a congressional ban, ordering officials to halt the terminations and restore workers to their positions.

U.S. District Judge Susan Illston of the Northern District of California said the administration broke its own agreement when it moved forward with layoffs affecting upwards about 675 employees at the Department of Education, State Department, Small Business Administration, and General Services Administration[1]. "The government did what it was ordered not to do," Illston said during a hearing in San Francisco[1].

The ruling centers on language in the continuing resolution passed by Congress and signed by President Trump on November 12, which ended the record 43-day government shutdown[2][3]. Section 120 of that law explicitly prohibits federal agencies from initiating or implementing any reduction-in-force actions through January 30, 2026[4][5].

items.title: US sea level rise has doubled in 125 years, study finds

featured_image.name: A Louisiana gas plant sea wall shows challenges of flooding, energy ...

items.description:
A comprehensive analysis of U.S. coastal sea levels published today reveals that rates of sea level rise have more than doubled over the past 125 years, directly contradicting a controversial Trump administration climate report from this summer.

The study, published in AGU Advances, found that average U.S. coastal sea level rise increased from less than 2 millimeters per year in 1900 to more than 4 millimeters per year by 2024[1][2]. This translates to nearly 16 inches of total rise over that period[1][2].

Chris Piecuch, a physical oceanographer at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution who conducted the research, analyzed data from 70 tide gauges distributed along the contiguous U.S. coast[1][2]. "When you consider all the available observations, the data point in the opposite direction—that U.S. coastal sea level is clearly on an accelerating course," he said[2].

items.title: AI systems tackle transformer limits, materials discovery

featured_image.name: AI materials discovery now needs to move into the real world

items.description:
Researchers unveiled two separate breakthroughs this week that leverage large language models to accelerate materials discovery and improve transformer architectures, addressing longstanding limitations in AI systems.

MIT and the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab introduced PaTH Attention, a new encoding technique that makes positional information in transformers adaptive and context-aware rather than static, according to a paper presented at the Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS) this month[1][2][3]. The development addresses a key limitation in how large language models track state changes and sequential reasoning over long texts.

Meanwhile, researchers from the Institute of Industrial Science at the University of Tokyo announced MatAgent, an AI framework built around a large language model that guides the search for new inorganic materials using natural language reasoning, according to a study published this month in Cell Reports Physical Science[4][5].

items.title: Trump defends record as economic approval hits new low

featured_image.name: Trump to Address Nation Tonight: Live Updates - The New York Times

items.description:
President Donald Trump defended his administration's record in a prime-time address from the White House on Wednesday, claiming he "inherited a mess" from former President Joe Biden while asserting he has brought "more positive change to Washington than any administration in American history"[1][2][3]. The speech comes as new polling shows Americans increasingly dissatisfied with his economic management.

Trump announced that 1.45 million military service members will receive $1,776 "warrior dividend" payments before Christmas, with checks "already on the way"[1][4][5]. The amount honors the nation's founding year, with the president suggesting the payments would be funded from tariff revenues[6].

The address arrives at a politically precarious moment for Trump. An NPR/PBS News/Marist poll released Tuesday found that 57 percent of Americans disapprove of his handling of the economy, compared with just 36 percent who approve—the lowest rating of either of his presidential terms[7][8][9]. His overall job approval stands at 38 percent, also the lowest of his second term[8][10].

items.title: US military kills four in Pacific vessel strike

featured_image.name: U.S. forces strike vessel linked to narco-terrorism in Eastern Pacific, 4 killed

items.description:
The US military carried out a lethal strike on a vessel in the eastern Pacific Ocean on Wednesday, killing four individuals described as "narco-terrorists," according to US Southern Command. The operation, conducted at the direction of Secretary of War Pete Hegseth under Joint Task Force Southern Spear, marks the 26th such strike since Operation Southern Spear began in early September, bringing the death toll to at least 99[1][2][3].

Intelligence confirmed the vessel was "transiting along a known narco-trafficking route in the Eastern Pacific and was engaged in narco-trafficking operations," Southern Command stated on social media[4][5]. The military released video footage showing a boat moving through water before exploding, though it provided no evidence of illicit cargo aboard[2][6].

The strike occurred the same day House Republicans narrowly defeated two Democratic-led resolutions that would have required President Donald Trump to seek congressional authorization before continuing the strikes or taking military action against Venezuela. A measure by Rep. Gregory Meeks of New York to halt strikes against "presidentially designated terrorist organizations" in the Western Hemisphere failed 210-216[3][7]. A second resolution by Rep. Jim McGovern of Massachusetts to block unauthorized military action against Venezuela fell 211-213[3][7].

items.title: NASA's Perseverance rover cleared for extended Mars mission to 2031

featured_image.name: NASA's Perseverance rover has embarked on a road trip on Mars

items.description:
NASA's Perseverance rover has traveled nearly 25 miles across Mars since landing in Jezero Crater almost five years ago, with new tests showing the vehicle remains in excellent condition to continue operations for at least another six years, mission officials announced this week at the American Geophysical Union's annual meeting in New Orleans[1][2].

The rover set a Mars driving record in June when it covered 1,350.7 feet in a single Martian day — eclipsing both its own previous record and the mark held by NASA's now-retired Opportunity rover[1][3]. That achievement, accomplished through autonomous navigation software, came as Perseverance traversed the challenging terrain of Jezero Crater, where scientists believe an ancient lake and river system once flowed.

"These tests show the rover is in excellent shape," said Steve Lee, Perseverance's deputy project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, who presented the findings Wednesday[1][2]. Over the past two years, engineers have evaluated nearly all of the rover's subsystems, certifying that critical components like wheel actuators can perform optimally for at least another 37 miles[1][2].

items.title: Satellite tech reveals thousands of U.S. dams are sinking

featured_image.name: 2,500 'high-risk' U.S. dams are sinking into the ground ...

items.description:
More than 2,500 high-risk dams across the United States are deteriorating in ways that traditional inspections cannot detect, according to new research from Virginia Tech scientists presented this week at the American Geophysical Union's Annual Meeting in New Orleans.

Using satellite-based Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar technology, researchers discovered that many dams previously believed to be stabilized are continuing to sink into the ground, potentially concealing internal structural damage from safety inspectors[1][2][3]. The findings arrive as the nation's aging dam infrastructure faces mounting pressure from underfunding and increasingly extreme weather events driven by climate change.

items.title: Trump to address nation as approval hits new lows

featured_image.name: Trump set to address the nation in primetime White House speech as Americans report economic squeeze

items.description:
President Donald Trump will deliver a prime-time address from the White House Wednesday evening as his approval ratings sink to near-record lows and Americans express mounting frustration over the economy, setting the stage for what could be a pivotal moment in his presidency ahead of the 2026 midterm elections.

The speech, scheduled for 9 p.m. EST, comes as Trump faces significant political headwinds. His overall approval rating has fallen to between 36% and 40% across recent polls, with his economic approval hitting a new low of 31% in an AP-NORC survey conducted December 4-8[1][2][3][4]. A separate NPR-PBS News-Marist poll released Wednesday found 70% of Americans have expenses that match or exceed their income every month, while seven in 10 said their area is not affordable for the average family[1].

"The message this evening is we inherited a mess and we've done a great job, and we continue to, and our country is going to be stronger than ever before very soon," Trump told reporters earlier Wednesday[2][5].

items.title: Medline shares surge in largest US IPO since 2021

featured_image.name: Medline Begins Trading On Nasdaq Exchange, To Be 2025's Largest IPO

items.description:
Medline Inc. shares soared 41% in their Nasdaq debut Wednesday, valuing the medical supply giant at roughly $46 billion at opening and capping the largest US initial public offering of the year[1][2][3].

The Northfield, Illinois-based company's stock opened at $35 and closed at $41, well above its IPO price of $29[1][2][4]. Medline raised $6.26 billion by selling 216 million shares, marking the biggest US IPO since Rivian Automotive's $13.7 billion offering in November 2021[2][5][3].

items.title: Warner Bros Discovery rejects Paramount's $108B takeover bid

featured_image.name: Warner Bros. board tells shareholders to reject Paramount offer in favor of Netflix

items.description:
Warner Bros Discovery urged shareholders on Wednesday to reject Paramount's hostile takeover bid, unanimously declaring the $108.4 billion offer inadequate and fraught with risk as the media giant stands by its agreement with Netflix[1][2][3].

The board accused Paramount of "consistently misleading" investors about financing commitments and criticized the bid for failing to address concerns raised during months of negotiations[4]. The rebuke, announced December 17, escalates one of Hollywood's most contentious takeover battles and sets the stage for Paramount to either raise its offer or appeal directly to shareholders before its January 8 deadline[5][6].
